title: When did Metallica make it big? - Quora

response.answer_text: That depends on what you mean by “make it big.” Let’s use a typical benchmark for band popularity: Arena shows. Meaning, the band’s ability to play the larger arenas (basketball/hockey arenas) that hold more than 10,000 people or more. Metallica became popular enough to headline arena shows after the release of their fourth studio album “And Justice For All” in 1988. What helped their popularity tremendously was the video for their song “One” from this album, which garnered tons of MTV play and introduced them to a whole new group of fans. They had already achieved a great deal of underground popularity, and prior to “And Justice For All” they were playing small theaters (capacity of 4,000–6,000, roughly) following the release of what many consider to be their “best” album, “Master of Puppets.” But with the release of “And Justice For All” and the video for “One,” they were an arena-headlining band that had indeed “made it big.” Now, they entered an entirely different stratosphere with the release of the “Black Album” in 1991. That album sold 16.4 million copies worldwide and cemented them as the most popular heavy metal band of all time, bar none. But the “Black Album” didn’t make them an arena band, they already were.

People were accusing Metallica of selling out during Master Of Puppets, which is kinda bullshit. They were accused of this because they had released on a major record label (Elektra Records) The fans started to realize that Metallica wasn’t underground anymore, and that they were going to explode and that they did. …And Justice For All sold 15,840,000 million copies! (GLOBALLY!!) Which continued to spring Metallica into popularity until it happened…THE BLACK ALBUM! This is by far Metallica’s most popular album, this is the album that people know songs off of. This is when they REALLY sold out, this was also the first album that didn’t have Metallica’s Thrash Metal roots in it, it was more on the heavy metal and hard rock side. This album has most of Metallica’s popular songs on it… Did someone say…Enter Sandman and Nothing Else Matters? This album has 30,379,000 million sales globally, compare that to the 8,510,000 sales that Kill ’Em All had, so the Black Album was when Metallica really boosted themselves into the spotlight.
